title: 109_s4055
content: The Act titled "Preserving Crime Victims' Restitution Act of 2006" addresses the effect of a defendant's death in federal criminal proceedings. The "Preserving Crime Victims' Restitution Act of 2006" amends Subchapter A of chapter 227 of title 18, United States Code, by adding a section on the effect of a defendant's death in Federal criminal proceedings. It states that the death of a defendant convicted of a Federal criminal offense does not invalidate a guilty plea, verdict, sentence, or judgment, except as provided in the section. The court shall enter a judgment incorporating the plea of guilty or nolo contendere or the verdict, with the notation that the defendant died before the judgment was entered. If a defendant dies after a plea or verdict but before sentencing, no sentence or penalties may be imposed. The death of a defendant after sentencing terminates any probation, supervision, or imprisonment, and any remaining liability for criminal forfeiture, fines, or special assessments. Restitution is not required, and any amounts already paid are not refunded. If a defendant dies after sentencing, any probation, supervision, or imprisonment is terminated, along with liability for criminal forfeiture, fines, or special assessments. Restitution is not required, and any amounts already paid are not refunded. If a defendant dies before sentencing, a special restitution proceeding may be initiated to enter a final order of restitution against the estate. The death of a defendant after sentencing does not invalidate restitution orders or prevent the use of guilty pleas or verdicts in civil proceedings. Appeals, motions, and petitions in criminal cases are limited after the defendant's death. After a defendant's death, no appeals or challenges to guilty pleas, verdicts, sentences, or judgments can be filed in the case. Any pending motions or appeals will be dismissed. Exceptions include restitution orders after a defendant's conviction in a criminal case. After a defendant's death, no appeals or challenges can be filed in the case, except for restitution orders in a criminal case. The personal representative, the Government, or any victim may pursue appeals or motions related to obtaining, enforcing, or challenging restitution orders. After a defendant's death, appeals or challenges cannot be filed in the case, except for restitution orders. The appeal, petition, or motion can challenge a verdict, guilty plea, sentence, or judgment if shown to be material in a civil proceeding. The Government cannot impose collateral consequences on the estate, except for restitution orders after a defendant's death. The Government cannot impose collateral consequences on the estate or family members of a deceased defendant based solely on the conviction if the defendant died before exhausting the right to appeal, unless notice is given within 90 days. If notice is given, a personal representative will be appointed for the deceased defendant. The death of a defendant does not provide a basis for relief in any appeal, petition, or motion. Procedures for continuing litigation include tolling filing deadlines until a personal representative is appointed for the deceased defendant. The death of a defendant does not provide relief in any appeal, petition, or motion. The court shall appoint a personal representative for the defendant if none exists, and counsel shall be appointed for the personal representative if requested and qualifies under section 3006A, with any deadlines for filing motions, petitions, or appeals being tolled. The death of a defendant does not provide relief in any appeal, petition, or motion. Special procedures apply if continuing litigation is initiated under subsection (c)(2), including notice to victims and appointment of a personal representative. Restitution owed by a deceased defendant in a criminal case can be collected from their property. Restitution owed by a deceased defendant in a criminal case can be collected from any property that could have been collected if the defendant had survived. Restitution protective orders remain in effect unless modified, and the court will take necessary actions to preserve the restitution upon motion by the Government or victims. The government can pursue civil forfeiture of property even after the death of an individual, with limitations on the time period extended by 2 years after the individual's death. The government can initiate civil forfeiture proceedings against any property alleged to be forfeitable in an indictment, even after the individual's death, with a 2-year extension period. The definitions in this section clarify terms related to guilty pleas, sentences, and convictions. The definitions in this section clarify terms related to guilty pleas, sentences, and convictions, including direct appeals and verdicts. The amendments made by this Act in Federal criminal proceedings apply to cases pending on or after July 1, 2006. If any provision is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act remains unaffected.
